   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Per report, patient was demonstrating increased
   work of breathing in the ED with resp rates in the 30s.  No ABG done
   prior to intubation.  Patient does have a history of COPD and CHF with
   last ECHO showing EF of 35-40%.  On arrival to the ICU, patient was
   demonstrated large negative pressures with low PIPs around 12.  Initial
   ABG was actually venous and was 7.16/56/48.  Repeat just after
   increased tidal volumes, ABG was 7.22/43/302 on FiO2 100%.  Likely has
   increased dead space in the setting of hypovolemia and hypoperfusion as
   well.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation as patient has component of respiratory acidosis in
   addition to non-AG metabolic acidosis
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.
   - Will check Urine AG
   - Nutrition consult for TPN
   - Avoid NS for resuscitation given hyperchloremia and hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   - Will cycle CE
   - Continue dilt gtt, will transition to home metoprolol as tolerated
   - IVF for dehydration
   - Continue to follow
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Will give D51/2NS now given dehydration and free water deficit
   - PM lytes
   - Urine lytes now
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12 and folate within
   normal limits.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Will send iron studies
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Continue coumadin 2.5 mg daily
   - Continue to trend INR
   - LUE US to rule out DVT at PICC site
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.
   - Urine lytes
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl
   - Will consult surgery for further recommendations regarding medical
   mgmt and abx course
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient
   .
   # Disposition: pending above
   .
   ICU Care

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF

   - Avoid nephrotoxins

   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold

   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt

   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd

   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for

   .

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and the need for intubation indicate a critical condition. The combination of IVF (inhalation of gastric contents), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib with RVR), and profound metabolic acidosis puts the patient at risk for further respiratory failure.

2. Fever: The patient has been febrile since admission, with a temperature of 101.2°F. The fever may be due to worsening of an underlying infection, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or an occult infectious process. The lack of elevated WBC count makes it difficult to determine the cause.

3. Tachycardia: The patient has a history of tachycardia, which was treated with IV lopressor and transitioned to PO lopressor during a previous admission. The rhythm is likely sinus tachycardia with atrioventricular blocks (APBs) or multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT). The patient is currently on diltiazem drip, which needs to be titrated down as tolerated and transitioned to home metoprolol when able to take oral medications.

4. Non-anion gap (NAG) metabolic acidosis: The patient has a NAG metabolic acidosis with a urine chloride level of 28 mEq/L. The differential diagnosis includes saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion), increased amino acids in total parenteral nutrition (TPN), or renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Further evaluation is needed to determine the exact cause.

5. Hypernatremia: The patient has ongoing hypernatremia, likely due to inadequate fluid resuscitation. The calculated free water deficit is 2.8 L, and the patient received 0.5 L of D51/2NS followed by 1.5 L of D5W overnight. Transitioning to D5W with 3 amps of sodium bicarbonate for intravenous fluids (IVF) is recommended.

6. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient appears dry on examination, suggesting pre-renal azotemia. However, there may be a component of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) or RTA contributing to the renal failure. FENa is 1.26%, indicating that it is not entirely pre-renal. IVF resuscitation, avoidance of nephrotoxins, renal dosing of medications, and a nephrology consult are necessary.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation and is now intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient was overbreathing
   the ventilator overnight when less sedated to increase pH and
   simultaneously driving down CO2.  Minute ventilation 12-17L/min.
   Patient has a history of COPD and likely chronically has a high CO2.
   Will not try to achieve his baseline CO2 currently as there is still an
   ongoing metabolic acidosis.
   - Continue to titrate vent settings to achieve target minute
   ventilation around 12-13 L/min
   - Will attempt to wean as acidosis improves
   - VAP precautions
   - Repeat CXR in am
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count.
   - Cont. cipro & flagyl
   - CT abdomen to examine for interval changes, worsening appendicitis
   vs. duodenal-pancreatic communication given low HCO3
   - f/u blood, urine, & sputum cultures
   - trend fever curve & WBC count.
   .
   # Tachycardia: Patient was noted to have tachycardia (afib vs ST vs
   MAT) during last admission which was treated with IV lopressor
   transitioned to PO lopressor.  A CTA at that time was negative for PE
   and CE ruled out MI.  Cardiology at that time felt that the rhythm was
   likely sinus tachy with APBs/MAT, and recommended watching as well as
   possibly initiating digoxin which was not started at that time.
   Patient has ruled out for an MI again.  Dilt drip stable at 10 mg/hr
   overnight with heart rates in the low 100s and SBP in the low 100s.
   Unable to transition to PO meds at this time as patient is NPO due to
   ruptured appendix.
   - Continue dilt gtt, titrate down as tolerated and transition to home
   metoprolol when able to take POs
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.
   - Switch to NaHCO3 for fluid resuscitation given hyperchloremia and
   hypernatremia
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Has been ongoing for several days at rehab.  Unclear
   if patient has received more than 1L of free water as it is not
   documented in NH paperwork.
   - Calculated free water deficit is 2.8L
   - Patient received 0.5 L D51/2NS then 1.5L D5W overnight.
   - transition to D5W + 3amps NaHCO3 for IVF
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient appears dry on exam.  Likely
   pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or ATN as above.  FENa
   1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - IVF resuscitation
   - Avoid nephrotoxins
   - Renally dose all meds
   - nephrology consult
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - As lactate wnl and patient appears dry with BP responding to fluid
   boluses, will continue cipro/flagyl for appendicitis as no other clear
   source of infection.  BPs currently normal
   - Low threshold to increase abx regimen should patient become unstable
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, nutrition consult for
   TPN recs
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, need to confirm placement, PIV, will place A-line
   today
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, need to talk with HCP regarding patient
   overall status once further info from CT available.
   .
   # Disposition: pending above

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, and congestive heart failure. He was admitted with hypernatremia and is now intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including fever, tachycardia, non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, right subclavian vein thrombosis, ruptured appendix, and a pancreatic mass.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure. Ventilator settings need to be titrated to achieve target minute ventilation and maintain adequate oxygenation.
2. Fever: The patient has a fever, which may indicate an ongoing infection, possibly related to the ruptured appendix or other sources such as aspiration pneumonitis or occult infectious process. Further investigation is needed, including cultures and imaging studies.
3. Tachycardia: The patient has a history of tachycardia, which could be related to atrial fibrillation or other causes. It is important to monitor heart rate and consider medications like beta-blockers to control the heart rate.
4. Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis: The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure or saline resuscitation. Sodium bicarbonate may be required for correction.
5. Hypernatremia

s HR has gone up, now

d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.

   - Consider adding oral BBker for rate control

   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is now intubated for respiratory failure and requires pressor support. He has a history of septic state, mixed venous O2 saturation indicating distributive shock, and a component of cardiogenic shock. The patient's heart rate has increased persistently in the 130s. He is on mechanical ventilation, and his ABG shows improved pH.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of IVF, atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis. There is a trial of pressure support ventilation in anticipation of weaning off the ventilator.
2. Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is most likely due to a septic state. There is a possibility of distributive shock, and the patient may also have a component of cardiogenic shock. The patient requires pressor support for blood pressure management.
3. Fever: The patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a ruptured appendix. The fever may represent worsening of this process, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or another occult infectious process.
4. Non-AG metabolic acidosis

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, impaired skin integrity, and atrial fibrillation. The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management of his conditions. He is receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and nutritional support through total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient has been experiencing fever, hypotension, and low urine output. Cultures have been obtained, and the patient is being treated empirically for potential infections. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's current presentation of fever, hypotension, and low urine output suggests sepsis, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention and management.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has a history of chronic renal failure, and his current condition may worsen due to inadequate renal function, leading to further fluid and electrolyte imbalances.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is at risk for DVT due to prolonged immobilization in the ICU. Regular assessment and prophylactic measures should be implemented to prevent this complication.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, as he may develop acute respiratory failure if his underlying lung condition deteriorates.
5. Infection Control: Proper infection control practices should be followed to minimize the risk of healthcare-associated infections,

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendix and recurrent hypotension with atrial fibrillation (A-Fib) upon admission. The patient has evidence of pre-renal azotemia and persistent hypotension, suggesting an alternative source of acute infection, such as a catheter-related blood stream infection or pneumonia. 

The patient is currently experiencing respiratory failure and requires ventilatory support. The plan is to attempt to wean off the ventilator today, depending on the patient's tolerance of pressure support ventilation (PSV) and improvement in blood bicarbonate levels (HCO3-).

Sepsis is also present, and the patient is on pressors, specifically levophed, and receiving vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam antibiotics. Follow-up culture results will be awaited, and coverage for fungal infection will be considered due to prolonged exposure to antibacterials and possible gastrointestinal source. IV fluids will be given as needed, and attempts will be made to wean off levophed as possible.

Atrial fibrillation is ongoing, with limited response to PRN IV medications. Rate control medications will be initiated as soon as possible. Diltiazem (Dilt) will be used as needed, and consideration will be given to cardioversion only for persistent and refractory hypotension despite pressors.

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is present and will be continued with

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Consider trial of phenylephrine instead of levophed to eliminate
   positive chronotropy
   - Consider adding oral BBker for rate control
   - Consider chemical cardioversion with amio
   - PE unlikely given pt has been on lovenox, now on heparin gtt.
   - Can discuss possible initiation of digoxin once ARF improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn yesterday given decompensation.
   - Add fluconazole for empiric coverage of fungal (stop TPN while
   getting treated for ?fungemia)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   - judicious use of normal saline
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - appreciate nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.  Cont. heparin gtt and hold
   coumadin as avoiding PO meds until further information from CT
   abdomen.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   .
   # Ruptured apendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - appreciate [**Doctor First Name **] recs
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, hold TPN while
   +suspicion of fungemia.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line, A-line, PIV. Likely needs a fem line given the
   number of IV medications pt is receiving.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, sepsis without organ dysfunction, deep vein thrombosis in the right upper extremity, hypernatremia, and impaired skin integrity. The patient has been receiving various medications and treatments, including antibiotics, vasopressors, and cardiac support. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia and hypotension, with a heart rate of 118 bpm and blood pressure ranging from 70/48 mmHg to 95/56 mmHg. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 13 breaths per minute. Laboratory results indicate elevated levels of creatinine, glucose, and lactic acid, as well as low albumin and potassium levels. Imaging studies show no significant changes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's history of sepsis without organ dysfunction indicates an increased risk for further infection and septic shock.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The presence of a DVT in the right upper extremity may lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism if not appropriately managed.
3. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure puts him at risk for further deterioration of kidney function, potentially leading to acute kidney injury.
4. Hypernatremia: The high sodium level can result in neurological complications, including seizures

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications. The patient has a history of chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, sepsis without organ dysfunction, impaired skin integrity, and deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity. The patient is also experiencing metabolic acidosis and hypernatremia.

The patient's vital signs indicate a fever with a maximum temperature of 38 degrees Celsius and a current temperature of 36.2 degrees Celsius. The patient's heart rate is elevated at 118 beats per minute, and blood pressure is on the lower side at 95/56 mmHg. The respiratory rate is within normal limits at 13 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is at 98% on mechanical ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatinine and potassium, as well as decreased levels of hemoglobin, albumin, and calcium. The white blood cell count is within normal range. The patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis.

In terms of treatment, the patient is receiving multiple medications including midazolam, heparin sodium, amiodarone, fentanyl, and norepinephrine. The patient is also on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, and the ventilator settings include a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O, and a FiO2 of 40%.

The patient's recent interventions include the placement of a right femoral central venous catheter, failed trials of neosynephrine, cardioversion attempts, and the use of levophed overnight. The patient has also been on prolonged sedation with midazolam and has had multiple blood cultures taken.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include worsening renal function, ventilator-associated pneumonia, deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and further cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring and appropriate management are essential for this critically ill patient.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendicitis, re-admitted with hypotension consistent with sepsis. He has been treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and PRN fluid bolus. The patient's heart rate has improved with Amiodarone, but cardioversion was unsuccessful. He is currently in persistent atrial fibrillation and requires continued treatment with Amiodarone.

The patient is experiencing shock, likely due to a combined septic and cardiogenic contribution. Efforts are being made to wean off Levophed and Vasopressin. The patient also has respiratory failure, with minimal secretions and tolerance of decreased PSV. An SBT was performed this morning, and ABG will be checked at 30 minutes. Anesthesia notes should be reviewed for airway difficulties. Metabolic issues, possible pulmonary edema, and poor mental status are also considerations.

The patient has acute renal failure with stable creatinine levels. HCO3- will be provided as needed for acidosis if it decreases below 16. Renal input is appreciated, and renal dosing of medications will be done. The patient has atrial fibrillation, which failed cardioversion, so Amiodarone will continue to be administered. There is a concern for thrombosis, specifically DVT, and Heparin will continue to be used. When the patient is stable, Coumadin will be initiated. Nutrition

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib/RVR) and required intubation for respiratory failure. The patient is currently in the ICU, receiving mechanical ventilation, and has multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of IVF (intravenous fluids), AFib with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis. He was not extubated last night due to hemodynamic instability. The plan is to try pressure support ventilation (PSV) in anticipation of weaning off the ventilator. If the respiratory system bilinear index (RSBI) and spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) are favorable, extubation may be considered later today. Issues that could complicate extubation include mental status (very sedated) and the need for a high minute volume to compensate for metabolic acidosis.

2. Hemodynamics: The patient has AFib with RVR, which is most likely due to septic state. He also has a history of AFib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed venous O2 saturation was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although the patient may have a component of cardiogenic shock, he did not

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male admitted to the ICU for sepsis without organ dysfunction, respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation, renal failure, and impaired skin integrity. The patient's condition has been complicated by several events over the past 24 hours. These include an increase in the level of vancomycin and the order for a new level, the initiation of tube feeds with nutrition, the placement of a central venous catheter (c/s), the restart of Coumadin due to its interaction with amiodarone, the unsuccessful extubation attempt due to poor gases, fluctuations in levophed dosage, tachycardia, hypotension, and the consultation of cardiology. The cardiology team recommended loading the patient with digoxin and repeating the dose in 6 hours. They also suggested checking the digoxin level on the next day and adjusting the dose accordingly. If the patient's blood pressure improves, they proposed considering metoprolol 2.5 mg IV and/or reloading amiodarone. The team also discussed the possibility of an ECHO for congestive heart failure given the patient's prolonged length of stay (>14 days).

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, the potential medical complications that can arise for this patient include:
1. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity.
2. Metabolic acidosis.
3. Sepsis without organ dysfunction.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and is now intubated for respiratory
   failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). ABG much better now
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat high suggestive of distributive shock. [**Month (only) 11**] also have a
   component of cardiogenic shock, however, given pt
s HR has gone up, now
   persistently in 130s. + pressor requirement for BP support. Dilt gtt
   was d/c
d yesterday. [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim checked (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 24 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation.
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: resolved.
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Transition to coumadin if extubated
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, TF/po intake post
   extubation
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from OSH
 will pull when hemodynamically stable),
   A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Was not extubated last night
   due to hemodynamic instability. Needs
   - Trial of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Try RSBI and SBT,
   if favorable, extubate later today
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (very sedated)
   and minute volume requirement required to compensate for metabolic
   acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Cardiology was consulted last night;
   recommended digoxin loading.
   - Continue chemical cardioversion with amio, digoxin (dose by level
   given ARF)
   - Wean levophed as tolerated by MAP > 65
   - f/u cardiology recs
   - consider repeating echo
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. some other occult
   infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC
   count and has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a
   robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically
   ill state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. There is a concern
   for fungal infection given pt
s prolonged abx course and frequent
   hospital stays.
   - Abx switched to Vanc/Zosyn [**4-23**] given decompensation. (Day 3 today)
   - Surveillance blood cultures
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   - ID denied empiric fluconazole; will f/u glucan and galactomannin and
   re-assess once data available.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis: resolved. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Got
   bicarb with IVF yesterday
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure: Patient now adequately fluid
   resuscitated.  Likely pre-renal though may have a component of RTA or
   ATN as above.  FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely pre-renal.
   - F/u nephrology recs
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Slightly decreased from
   prior.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional.  He was noted to be anemic with
   guaiac positive stools during last admission.  B12,  folate, & iron
   within normal limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase
   reactant and should be rechecked).  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT.
   - Given acute renal failure, will hold lovenox and continue heparin gtt
   started in ED
   - Transition to coumadin if extubated
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  He is likely due
   to complete a course of flagyl/cipro in the next several days. Rec'd
   one dose of vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  Surgery
   recommended reimaging abdomen.
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn for broad spectrum coverage in the absence
   of specific microbio data
   - [**Doctor First Name 3**] recs: OK to feed
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: IVF, replete electrolytes, NPO for now, TF/po intake post
   extubation
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with heparin gtt, lansoprazole
   (is on omeprazole as o/p as well), bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from OSH
 will pull when hemodynamically stable),
   A-line, R fem CVC [**4-23**]
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care

The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, hemodynamics instability, fever, non-AG metabolic acidosis, acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, right subclavian vein thrombosis, ruptured appendicitis, and pancreatic mass.

3. Fever: The patient has had intermittent fevers, which may indicate worsening of the ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonia, or another occult infection. Surveillance blood cultures and further evaluation for infectious causes are recommended.

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendicitis, currently admitted with significant tachycardia and hypotension, persistent atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and associated hypotension. The patient is intubated due to respiratory failure secondary to initial sepsis, cardiogenic shock with atrial fibrillation, and rapid ventricular response. 

Assessment and plan:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on atropine and assisted ventilation support overnight. Today, he will have a trial of pressure support ventilation (PSV) to evaluate his capacity to tolerate extubation. If he is unable to tolerate spontaneous breathing trials (SBT), it may indicate that diuresis and improved rate control/return to sinus rhythm are needed for success.
2. Sepsis: The source of sepsis remains to be defined. Vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam will continue for a 10-day course. Follow-up culture results will be monitored, and pressors will be weaned as sedation is weaned around extubation. Diuresis may be considered if possible, and fungal cultures will be followed.
3. Venous Thrombosis: Heparin GTT (gradual titration therapy) will continue, and Coumadin has been started for long-term anticoagulation since no procedures are currently planned.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and previous sepsis. He presented to the ICU with acute respiratory failure and hypotension. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. He is receiving multiple medications, including sedatives, pain management, and antibiotics.

24-hour events:
- Renal: The patient experienced non-oliguric renal failure with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) secondary to hypotension. Diuretics were not given due to the patient's positive fluid balance. Continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) is not required at this time.
- Pulmonary: The patient's partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) and oxygen saturation (SpO2) are within normal range. The respiratory rate (RR) is slightly elevated, and the tidal volume (Vt) is set at 500 mL.
- Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure (BP) is low, and he is on norepinephrine to maintain adequate blood pressure. His heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation (AFib), and the heart rate (HR) is tachycardic.

Allergies:
The patient has no known drug allergies.

   81 yo male with history of ruptured appendicitis and now with
   readmission with clinical picture consistent with sepsis and source
   remains to be defined.  This in addition has associated metabolic
   acidosis and peristent mild renal failure.  His recent picture has been
   one of failed capacity to tolerate wean in ventilatory support and wean
   of pressor support for hypotension.  This again, is all in the absence
   of significant cluture or radiographic evidence of focal source of
   infection.  His clinical picture is one of progressive decline in terms
   of respiratory status and no expectation to be able to successfully
   wean from ventilator.  His atrial fibrillation has been able to be
   better rate controlled and patient has failed cardioversion and
   amiodarone to trial to achieve sinus rhythm.  In addition he has
   persistent hypotension which has required increased pressor
   requirements.
   1)Respiratory Failure
he is limited by mental status and worsening
   secretions and inability to maintain effective ventilation
   -Patient to PSV to trial today
   -Continue Rx for possible pneumonia-_Vanco/Zosyn continued at D#4
   -Will continue to wean sedation as possible
   2)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Amiodarone
   -ECHO today
   -Cardiology to evaluate patient for possible alternative approaches to
   stabilize rhythm
   3)DVT-
   Heparin to Coumadin
   4)Sepsis-
   -Foley changed following fungal culture in urine
   -Continue with broad spectrum ABX
   -Continue with levophed.
   -Re-culture for spike.
   5)Renal Failure-
   -Patient total body overloaded
   -Cr has shown minimal change but significantly impaired
   -Continue to look for opportunity for diuresis and will use leveophed
   to maintain BP
   -Would not offer dialysis at this time
   -Lasix gtt. And will start with bolus

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendicitis and readmission for clinical sepsis. He also has associated metabolic acidosis and persistent mild renal failure. The patient has failed to tolerate weaning in ventilatory support and weaning of pressor support for hypotension. There is no significant culture or radiographic evidence of a focal source of infection. His clinical picture is one of progressive decline in respiratory status, and there is no expectation to successfully wean from the ventilator. He also has atrial fibrillation that has been better rate-controlled but failed cardioversion and amiodarone to achieve sinus rhythm. Additionally, the patient has persistent hypotension requiring increased pressor requirements.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's inability to maintain effective ventilation and worsening secretions pose a risk of respiratory failure.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may progress, leading to further heart rhythm disturbances and potential complications such as thromboembolism.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Given the patient's immobility and other risk factors, there is a risk of developing DVT.
4. Sepsis: The patient's septic state can worsen, potentially leading to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
5. Renal Failure: The patient's renal function

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical conditions. Here is a summary of the information:

1. The patient has been receiving Lasix (furosemide) intravenously, which suggests the presence of fluid overload or heart failure.
2. The patient is suspected to have a pulmonary embolism (PE), as indicated by persistent tachycardia despite anticoagulation therapy. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) has been ordered to further evaluate this possibility.
3. The patient has been given a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) to improve intravascular volume, likely due to hypotension or anemia.
4. The patient's likely wish is for interventions that are reversible or will provide comfort, indicating a discussion about end-of-life care.
5. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including midazolam, fentanyl, amiodarone, norepinephrine, and furosemide.
6. The patient has a history of chronic renal failure (CRF) and is receiving nutrition through a feeding tube.
7. The patient has impaired skin integrity, possibly due to immobility or pressure ulcers.
8. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a CPAP/PSV mode, set Vt of 500 mL, PS of 15 cmH2O, RR set at 18, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 40%, and other parameters.
9. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia (HR 119 bpm), hypertension (BP 116/62 mmHg), and hypoxemia (SpO2 96%).
10. The patient's laboratory results indicate hypernatremia (Na 147 mg/dL), chronic kidney disease (Hct 27.1%), and elevated lactate levels (0.9 mmol/L).

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:

1. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient's persistent tachycardia and the suspicion of PE indicate a potential complication related to thromboembolic disease.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): Although not explicitly mentioned, the patient's respiratory failure and the use of mechanical ventilation raise the possibility of ARDS.
3. Sepsis: The presence of fever, leukocytosis, and elevated lactate levels suggest the possibility of an ongoing infection leading to sepsis.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's impaired mobility and hypercoagulable state due to chronic renal failure may predispose him to developing DVT.
5. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's pre-existing chronic kidney disease, along with potential factors like sepsis, hypotension, or nephrotoxic medications, could lead to further deterioration

   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.

   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to

   15/5 better this AM than previously.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat
   RSBI
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (gets agitated
   when awake and overbreathes the vent to RR of 40) and minute volume
   requirement required to compensate for metabolic acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. He is currently intubated for respiratory failure and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient has a fever and is suspected to have an occult infection. He has positive B-glucan levels indicating possible fungal infection, and his sputum and urine cultures are positive for yeast. MRSA screen is also positive. He is being treated with ciprofloxacin, flagyl, vancomycin, and zosyn for his infections. Fluconazole has been started for suspected fungemia.

The patient has acute on chronic renal failure with a creatinine level of 1.8. He is receiving lasix for volume resuscitation and close monitoring of renal function is advised.

The patient has anemia with a baseline hemoglobin of 37 g/dL. He is stable on transfusions and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of his anemia.

The patient has a right subclavian vein thrombosis and is on lovenox and coumadin for anticoagulation. His INR is subtherapeutic.

The patient's condition requires ICU level of care while intubated.

   81 yo male with ruptured appendicitis now with prolonged respiratory
   failure and hypotension with multiple contributing factors including
   sepsis, atrial-fibrillation, possible right heart compromise and
   intra-vascular depletion.  He, thanks to cardiology input, has had
   transfusion of 2 units PRBC and been able to have some significant

   1)Respiratory Failure-

10 day course

   -Amiodarone
   -Coumadin
   -Digoxin
will need to clarify goals of the Digoxin
   -TEE and cardioversion if cardiology would feel we have a reasonable
   chance of success
urgency will depend on capacity to maintain pressors
   off.
   3)Altered Mental Status-
   -Will wean sedation as possible today
   -Likely multifactorial
   -Patient with increased alertness this morning which is encoura
   4)Acute Renal Failure-
   -Bicarb with substantial improvement with support of renal function
   5)Hematuria-
   -Will need follow up evaluation and if clots worsening with obstruction
   will move to 3-way foley

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ruptured appendicitis, prolonged respiratory failure, hypotension, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, possible right heart compromise, and intra-vascular depletion. He has received a transfusion of 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBC) and has shown some improvement with weaning of pressors. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has limited secretions. He is also experiencing altered mental status, acute renal failure, and hematuria. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (99°F), heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure of 93/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and he has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 24 mmHg. His laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.1 K/uL, elevated lactate level of 9.5 mmol/L, and elevated troponin-T level of 0.08 ng/mL. The patient's medications include midazolam, fentanyl, amiodarone, norepinephrine, and lasix. The plan includes continuing with vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for a 10-day course, starting flucon

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). More alert and tolerating PS
   15/5 better this AM than previously.
   - Continue trials of PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat
   RSBI
   - Issues that could complicate extubation: mental status (gets agitated
   when awake and overbreathes the vent to RR of 40) and minute volume
   requirement required to compensate for metabolic acidosis.
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. Discuss switching to PO amio and d/c
   digoxin
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue lasix (started yesterday [**4-26**]) with goal 1L negative today
   .
   # Fever: Patient has been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 48 hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 6
   today)
   - Start fluconazole today for fungemia
   - Surveillance blood cultures - NGTD
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Non-AG metabolic acidosis. Differential includes saline
   resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure (decreased acid excretion),
   increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA.  Urine lytes with anion gap.  Has
   received Bicarb. Likely to improve with diuresis.
   - Continue to trend
   .
   # Hypernatremia: was resolving, however borderline high again in the
   setting of restarting tube feeds.
   - increase free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Cr stable at 1.8
 2.0. Patient now
   adequately fluid resuscitated. FENa 1.26%, so likely not entirely
   pre-renal.
   - monitor closely as lasix is being given
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable x 3+ days.  [**Month (only) 11**] be partially dilutional (LOS 15L positive).  He
   was noted to be anemic with guaiac positive stools during last
   admission.  B12,  folate, & iron  within normal limits (though ferritin
   may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and should be rechecked).
   [**Month (only) 11**] be partially related to CKD.
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now started
   coumadin for bridge on [**4-18**]. INR subtherapeutic at rehab as well as
   here. Goal INR [**3-8**].  Also appears to have erythema and swelling of RUE
   to mid-arm.  Left arm without any DVT. INR therapeutic at 2.2.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**7-17**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also adding
   fluconazole today

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient is intubated for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation. He has multiple medical complications including fever, non-AG metabolic acidosis, hypernatremia, acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, right subclavian vein thrombosis, ruptured appendicitis, and pancreatic mass.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to a combination of factors such as IVF, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and profound metabolic acidosis. Weaning off the ventilator may be challenging due to mental status changes and increased minute volume requirements.
2. Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, likely due to septic state. There may be a component of cardiogenic shock, but the patient did not respond well to diltiazem or metoprolol. The mixed venous O2 saturation is high, suggesting distributive shock. The patient has been adequately fluid resuscitated, and weaning of levophed should be done carefully.
3. Fever: The patient has been on ciprofloxacin and flagyl for medical management of ruptured appendicitis.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently admitted to the ICU with several medical conditions. The patient has a history of chronic renal failure and sepsis without organ dysfunction. They are also experiencing acidosis, metabolic, hypernatremia, fever, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, acute impaired skin integrity, and a deep venous thrombosis in the upper extremity.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 101 bpm (normal range: 88-118 bpm), blood pressure ranging from 109/55 mmHg to 114/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute (normal range: 15-34 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 97%.

The patient's respiratory support includes being on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 40%, and respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 77. The arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.44, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 38 mmHg, partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) of 240, bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 95 mEq/L, and base excess (BE) of -1.8 mEq/L.

In terms of fluid balance, the patient has received a total of 3,303 mL of fluids since midnight, with an output of 4,700 mL of urine. The patient's blood pressure and heart rate are relatively stable, although there is a slight increase in heart rate during periods of weaning off from norepinephrine infusion.

The patient's lab results show elevated levels of white blood cells (WBC), hematocrit (Hct), and platelets (Plt). The kidney function tests indicate elevated levels of creatinine (Cr) and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). The liver function tests show elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase (Alk Phos), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and troponin-T. The electrolyte levels are within normal ranges except for a slightly low potassium level (K+).

The patient's medication changes include starting fluconazole for a positive beta glucan, decreasing warfarin dosage due to drug interactions, and adjusting the amiodarone regimen. The patient's pain management involves midazolam and fentanyl infusions. Norepinephrine infusion has been weaned off but kept at a low dose overnight.

Overall, the patient's condition appears stable with ongoing management of their multiple medical complications. Close monitoring of vital signs, fluid balance, and lab parameters is crucial to ensure proper treatment and prevent potential medical complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS 12/5 well this
   morning, but NIF only -11.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **].
   -
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs last night per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and subsequently intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has several medical complications that require attention.

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still on mechanical ventilation due to profound metabolic acidosis and agitation. It is important to continue weaning off the ventilator gradually, monitoring RSBI and NIF daily.

2. Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, likely due to septic state. Cardiology recommends continuing amiodarone and minimizing sedation as the patient becomes hypotensive easily.

3. Abdominal pain: The patient has a history of ruptured appendicitis, which is being managed medically with ciprofloxacin and Flagyl. The fever may be related to worsening of the appendicitis or other infectious processes. A CT scan showed no drainable abscesses, but the patient has a positive beta-glucan indicating possible fungal infection. Surveillance blood cultures should be obtained, and the patient should be started on fluconazole.

4. Non-AG metabolic acidosis: This could be due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids in TPN, or RTA. The patient has received bicarbonate and the acidosis

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and subsequently intubated for respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, likely due to a combination of IV fluid administration, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and profound metabolic acidosis. He is tolerating pressure support ventilation better now and continues to be monitored for extubation readiness. However, mental status and minute volume requirements may complicate extubation.

Hemodynamically, the patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which is most likely due to septic state. There is also a suspicion of pulmonary embolism based on an echocardiogram, but the patient is already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes a CT angiography of the chest.

The patient has a fever, possibly representing worsening of the ruptured appendix, aspiration pneumonia from intubation, or another occult infectious process. The patient has been on ciprofloxacin and Flagyl for the ruptured appendix, but the B-glucan is positive, indicating possible fungemia. MRSA screen is positive as well.

The patient has a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, possibly due to saline resuscitation, diarrhea, renal failure, increased amino acids from total parenteral nutrition (TPN), or renal tubular acidosis (RTA). Urine electrolytes with anion gap are present, and bicarbonate has been given. The hypernatremia is borderline high again, possibly due to tube feeds.

The patient has acute-on-chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level stable at 1.8 and FENa at 1.26%, suggesting it is not entirely pre-renal. Lasix is being given to promote diuresis and close monitoring is required.

Anemia is present, likely due to gastrointestinal bleeding from previous admissions and chronic kidney disease (CKD). Trending the anemia and conducting further tests, such as B12, folate, and iron levels, is recommended.

The patient has a right subclavian vein thrombosis, with significant erythema and edema of the right upper extremity. He has been on low molecular weight heparin (lovenox) and now started on warfarin.

Lastly, the patient has a ruptured appendicitis, medically managed with ciprofloxacin and Flagyl. His inflammatory markers are within normal limits, and CT abdomen shows no drainable fluid collection. Vanc/Zosyn and fluconazole have been added to the treatment regimen.

In summary, the patient's current conditions include respiratory failure, septic state with atrial fibrillation, possible pulmonary embolism, fever with suspicion of fung

   chest.

He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and is currently intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has multiple medical complications including abdominal pain, fever, acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, right subclavian vein thrombosis, ruptured appendicitis, pancreatic mass, and electrolyte imbalances. He is on multiple medications including antibiotics, antifungals, sedatives, analgesics, and cardiac medications. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to a combination of factors including IVF (inhalation of gastric contents), atrial fibrillation with RVR, and profound metabolic acidosis. The patient is tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV) well, but has poor negative inspiratory force (NIF). Therefore, the plan is to continue PSV and repeat respiratory system assessment and NIF daily.

2. Hemodynamics: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR in the setting of acute illness. The mixed venous oxygen saturation is high, suggesting distributive shock. Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). The patient is currently intubated for respiratory failure and has been on mechanical ventilation support.
