   Assessment and PlanThis is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p
   resection, prostate ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD,
   SVT, CHF and ruptured appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with
   hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for
   respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16). Tolerating PS better each
   day, although RSBI was 158 early this morning.
   - Continue PSV in anticipation of weaning off vent. Repeat RSBI/NIF
   daily-[**Hospital1 **]. (RSBI 90-100 and NIF -18 during rounds)
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - On very low dose levophed at this time (0.02 mcg/kg/min); suspect
   will be able to wean it off completely once all sedation is lifted.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   .
   # Abdominal pain: difficult to assess as pt
s sensorium is not
   completely clear, however it
s worrisome given his history of medically
   managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling well (1-3 times a day),
   C.diff neg x 1, and has no residuals with TF. KUB neg for ileus or
   obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL. Repeat C-diff pending.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis.  Fever may represent worsening of this process
   vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious
   process.  Notably, the patient does not have an elevated WBC count and
   has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may not be able to mount a robust
   inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill
   state. CT negative for any drainable abscesses. B-glucan floridly
   positive (>500) which is not surprising given pt
s prolonged abx
   courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN. Yeast in urine and
   sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative [**4-25**]; repeat pending
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 8
   today)
   - On day 3 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (Day
   3 today)
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   ..
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W x 1L yesterday.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.6. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.2 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - Cont warfarin
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Will continue vanc/zosyn Day [**9-16**] (started [**4-22**]) for broad spectrum
   coverage in the absence of specific microbio data; also started Fluc on
   [**4-27**] for + B-glucan
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled yesterday.
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care while intubated

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and intubated for respiratory failure. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation (CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow) with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 18 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's blood pressure is 94/45 mmHg and heart rate is 96 beats per minute.

The patient's medical complications include respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation with RVR, acute kidney injury (AKI), anemia, hypernatremia, and right subclavian vein thrombosis. The patient has a history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis and pancreatic mass.

The patient's current medications include fentanyl, midazolam, norepinephrine, Vancomycin, fluconazole, and Piperacillin.

The patient's recent lab results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 7.4 K/uL, normal hemoglobin level of 10.0 g/dL, elevated serum creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL,

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a prolonged hospital course due to recent ruptured appendix and prolonged respiratory failure. The patient has experienced sepsis and hemodynamic instability, which has been complicated by atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR). 

The potential medical complications that can arise from the conditions mentioned in the note are as follows:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient continues to have difficulty with ventilator weaning, indicating a potential risk of persistent respiratory failure. This may be attributed to significant muscle weakness.

2. Sepsis/Hypotension: Although the patient's fever is controlled and cultures remain negative, there is still a risk of sepsis-related hypotension. Appropriate antibiotic therapy with Zosyn and Vancomycin is being administered, and efforts will be made to wean off Levophed (a vasopressor) as possible.

3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient is being treated with Amiodarone to maintain good rate control. Anticoagulation is also being continued due to other reasons.

4. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient is receiving anticoagulation therapy with Coumadin to prevent further clot formation.

Other ICU care includes nutrition support through Nutren Renal (Full), glycemic control, and appropriate prophylaxis measures such as stress ulcer prevention, deep vein thrombosis prevention, and ventilator

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix.
- He was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and subsequently intubated for respiratory failure.
- The patient tolerated pressure support ventilation (PSV) well each day, but has not yet been extubated due to barriers such as anxiety and poor negative inspiratory force (NIF).
- The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the setting of acute illness in the past. He may have a component of cardiogenic shock, but did not benefit much from diltiazem or metoprolol. His TSH and FT4 levels are within normal limits.
- The patient has been systemically anticoagulated, and an echocardiogram is highly suspicious for pulmonary embolism (PE), but he is already anticoagulated and has renal failure precluding a CT angiogram (CTA) chest.
- The patient is on very low-dose levophed and is expected to be able to wean it off once all sedation is lifted.
- He is not receiving lasix at this time as he is autodiuresing post-acute tubular necrosis (ATN).
- The patient has abdominal pain, which is difficult to assess due to his altered mental status

Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise in this patient's case:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to respiratory failure, which is likely a combination of intravenous fluids (IVF), atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR), and profound metabolic acidosis. The patient tolerated pressure support ventilation (PSV) this morning with negative inspiratory force (NIF) +28. The plan is to attempt extubation today, but barriers include the patient's anxiety level and poor NIF (weakness).

2. Hemodynamics: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. The mixed venous O2 saturation was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although the patient may have a component of cardiogenic shock, they did not see much benefit from diltiazem (dilt) gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. The patient's heart rate came down from 110s-130s to 90-100s after being transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) per cardiology recommendation. An echocardiogram (Echo) was highly suspicious for pulmonary embolism (PE), but the patient is already systemically anticoagulated and has renal failure precluding computed tomography angiography (CTA) chest. Levophed was turned off.

3. Fever: The patient had been on ciprofloxacin/flagyl for medical management of a ruptured appendix with course to end on [**4-22**]. Fever may represent worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation vs. other occult infectious process. Notably, the patient does not have an elevated white blood cell (WBC) count and has been afebrile for 72+ hours. The patient may not be able to mount a robust inflammatory response due to older age and general chronically ill state. A CT scan was negative for any drainable abscesses. Beta-glucan was floridly positive (>500), which is not surprising given the patient's prolonged antibiotic courses, frequent hospital stays, and history of total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Yeast in urine and sputum were noted. MRSA screen was positive.

4. Abdominal pain: Absent today. Previously, it was difficult to assess as the patient's sensorium was not completely clear, however it was worrisome given his history of medically managed ruptured appendix. The patient is stooling well (1-3 times a day), Clostridium difficile (C. diff) negative x 2, and has no residuals with tube feeding (TF). Kidneys, ureters, and bladder (KUB) were negative for ileus or obstruction. Liver function tests (LFTs), amylase, and lip

   instability which has been complicated by a-fib with RVR which has
   shown increasing stability in the setting of Amiodarone and improved
   volume status.  He has had continued difficulty with ventilator weaning

   concerning for significant muscle weakness.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-inch tall individual who was admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. They were successfully extubated today and their Coumadin dose was increased to 2.5 mg daily, with an INR of 2.3 this morning. The patient's sodium level was corrected with a D5W 500cc bolus. They have been receiving various antibiotics since April 29th, including fluconazole, vancomycin, piperacillin, and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn). The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 103 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 135/64 to 145/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on a nasal cannula. The patient is currently on CPAP/PSV mode with a set volume of 500 mL and a spontaneous volume of 380 mL. Other parameters include a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, respiratory system compliance (RSBI) of 92, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 36 cmH2O, negative inspiratory force (NIF) of -27 cmH2O, and minute ventilation (Ve) of 12.3 L/min. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.44, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 44 mmHg, oxygen saturation (SaO2) of 92%, and partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) / FiO2 ratio of 232.

Physical examination findings include unassessed peripheral vascular status, skin, and neurologic assessment. Lab results indicate an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 270 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin (Hgb) of 9.6 g/dL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 115 mEq/L, elevated creatinine (Cr) of 1.6 mg/dL, and elevated potassium (K+) of 28.3%. Other lab values are within normal ranges.

Assessment and plan include acidosis, metabolic; deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity; sepsis without organ dysfunction; fever; hypernatremia; renal failure, chronic; atrial fibrillation; acute respiratory failure (not ARDS); impaired skin integrity.

ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, and various lines such as a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line and an arterial line. Prophylactic measures include DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) prophylaxis.

   Assessment and Plan
   This is an 81 yo M with history of lung cancer s/p resection, prostate
   ca s/p hormonal therapy and XRT as well as COPD, SVT, CHF and ruptured
   appendix on medical therapy who was admitted with hypernatremia and
   atrial fibrillation with RVR and was intubated for respiratory failure.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Likely a combination of IVF, afib with RVR, and
   profound metabolic acidosis that the patient was attempting to
   compensate for (initial pH on floor 7.16).   Patient tolerated PSV this
   morning with NIF +28.
   - attempt extubation today
   - Barriers to extubation: anxiety level, poor NIF (weakness).
   - OOB into chair today (PT consult)
   .
   # Hemodynamics: A fib with RVR most likely due to septic state. Pt has
   h/o afib with RVR in the setting of acute illness in the past. Mixed
   venous O2 Sat was high, suggesting distributive shock. Although pt may
   have a component of cardiogenic shock, pt did not see much benefit from
   dilt gtt or metoprolol PO/IV. Appropriate response to [**Last Name (un) 1398**] stim
   (14.6->28.5). TSH, FT4 WNL. Was transfused 2 u pRBCs 3/24 per
   Cardiology who felt pt was intravascularly volume depleted, and HR came
   down from 110s-130s to 90-100s. Echo highly suspicious for PE, however
   pt already systemically anticoagulated and renal failure precludes CTA
   chest.  Levophed off.
   - Appreciate cardiology recs. On PO amio now with rate mostly in
   90s-110s.
   - No lasix at this time as pt auto-diuresing post-ATN
   - pt. was on metoprolol as an outpatient for rate control, can consider
   restarting as BP improves
   .
   # Fever: Patient had been on cipro/flagyl for medical management of a
   ruptured appendicitis with course to end on [**4-22**].  Fever may represent
   worsening of this process vs. aspiration pneumonitis from intubation
   vs. other occult infectious process.  Notably, the patient does not
   have an elevated WBC count and has been afebrile x 72+ hours. Pt may
   not be able to mount a robust inflammatory response due to older age
   and general chronically ill state. CT negative for any drainable
   abscesses. B-glucan floridly positive (>500) which is not surprising
   given pt
s prolonged abx courses, frequent hospital stays and h/o TPN.
   Yeast in urine and sputum. MRSA screen pos.
   - C. diff negative x 2
   - Cont Vanc/Zosyn started [**4-22**] given initial decompensation. (Day 9
   today). Plan for 10 day total course
   - On day 4 of fluconazole which was started for positive B-glucan (D1 =
   [**4-27**]).  Plan for 7 day course?
   - f/u pending microbio studies.
   .
   # Abdominal pain: Absent today.  Previously was difficult to assess as
   pt
s sensorium was not completely clear, however it was worrisome given
   his history of medically managed ruptured appendicitis. Pt is stooling
   well (1-3 times a day), C.diff neg x 2, and has no residuals with TF.
   KUB neg for ileus or obstruction. LFTs, amylase, lipase all WNL.
   - Will hold off on further investigation for now; talk to patient once
   extubated for better history. The next step would be CT of abdomen and
   pelvis.
   - Continue TF as tolerating well with no residuals.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: better with D5W.
   - hold off on further D5W infusions; give PRN after checking PM lytes
   - continue free water boluses to 250 cc q4h
   - monitor
   .
   # Acute on chronic renal failure:  Resolving. Cr better this morning at
   1.3. UOP very good with likely post-ATN diuresis.
   - monitor Cr
   - renally dose meds
   .
   # Anemia: Baseline appears to be around 37.  Currently in the high20s,
   stable after 2 u pRBCs on [**4-26**].   B12,  folate, & iron  within normal
   limits (though ferritin may be elevated as an acute phase reactant and
   should be rechecked once pt recovers from acute illness).  [**Month (only) 11**] be
   partially related to CKD. Also having low grade hematuria (pink urine)
   off and on (with anticoagulation/INR 2.2)
   - Continue to trend
   - Active T&S
   - Guaiac all stools
   - monitor hematuria
   .
   # Right subclavian vein thrombosis: Significant erythema and edema of
   RUE.  Has been on lovenox since admission to rehab, now on coumadin
   with INR therapeutic 2.0 today (goal [**3-8**]). Left arm without any DVT.
   - increase warfarin again to 2.5 mg as INR barely therapeutic
   - f/u INR given concurrent administration of amiodarone and fluconazole
   .
   # Ruptured appendicitis, medically managed: Has been on Cipro/flagyl
   since last admission. Has been afebrile and currently has no
   leukocytosis and only a mild left shift at 77 PMNs.  Rec'd one dose of
   vanc/zosyn in ED due to hypotension, lactate wnl.  CT abdomen showing
   no drainable fluid collection
   - Vanc/zosyn and fluconazole as above
   - TF started [**4-24**]
   .
   # Pancreatic mass: Followed as o/p and appears to have been stable on
   repeat imaging.
   - Outpatient follow up
   .
   # FEN: replete electrolytes, TF with free water flushes held pending
   extubation.  Will try on clears later today if successfully extubated
   and has a good gag.
   .
   # Prophylaxis: systemic anticoagulation with warfarin, lansoprazole,
   bowel regimen
   .
   # Access: PICC line (from last admission; will not d/c at this time
   since other sites are inaccessible due to large clots), A-line; R fem
   CVC pulled [**4-28**].
   .
   # Code: Full
   .
   # Communication: Patient, HCP [**Name (NI) 4955**] [**Name (NI) 4961**] (neighbor; number in
   chart)
   .
   # Disposition: requires ICU level of care, if does well post
   extubation, potential c/o to floor tomorrow.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, SVT, CHF, and ruptured appendix. The patient was admitted with hypernatremia and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and was intubated for respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure. The barriers to extubation include anxiety level and poor negative inspiratory force (NIF).
2. Hemodynamics: The patient has atrial fibrillation with RVR, which is likely due to septic state. There is a concern for distributive shock, and the patient has been transfused with 2 units of packed red blood cells (pRBCs).
3. Fever: The patient had been on ciprofloxacin and flagyl for medical management of ruptured appendicitis. The fever may represent worsening of this process, aspiration pneumonitis from intubation, or other occult infectious process. The patient does not have an elevated WBC count, and has been afebrile for 72+ hours.
4. Abdominal pain: The patient previously had abdominal pain, but it is now absent. This could be due to the resolution of the ruptured appendix or other abdominal issues.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are improving with D5W.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of lung cancer, prostate cancer, COPD, atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, and ruptured appendix. He was admitted with hypernatremia and respiratory failure, for which he was intubated. The patient's respiratory failure has resolved, and he was successfully extubated yesterday. He is now breathing well on a nasal cannula with 50% FiO2.

The patient's hemodynamics are better controlled, but he still has a low heart rate. The plan is to continue administering amiodarone to control his heart rate. No lasix is needed at this time as the patient is auto-diuresing post-acute tubular necrosis (ATN).

The patient had a fever, which may represent worsening of a ruptured appendicitis, aspiration pneumonitis, or another occult infectious process. The B-glucan test was positive, indicating a possible fungal infection. The patient also has yeast in his urine and sputum, and a MRSA screen is positive. CT abdomen shows no drainable fluid collection. The patient is currently on vancomycin and Zosyn for the infection. Fluconazole will be discontinued soon if the patient continues to do well.

The patient had hypernatremia, which is improving with D5W. Further D5W infusions will be given PRN after checking potassium levels. The patient will also receive

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient, an 81-year-old male, has been admitted to the ICU with a prolonged hospital course following a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (APP) and respiratory failure. He has a history of sepsis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity, renal failure, and a pancreatic mass. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure ranging from 137/70 mmHg to 145/89 mmHg, heart rate of 106 bpm, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on a nasal cannula. The patient's fluid balance indicates an intake of 1,280 mL, output of 3,105 mL, and a negative balance of -1,825 mL. The patient is currently extubated and using an incentive spirometer. Laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but elevated creatinine and blood glucose levels. The patient's electrolytes are within normal limits. The assessment and plan include treatment for acute respiratory failure, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, DVT, renal failure, pancreatic mass, hypertension, and hypernatremia. The patient will continue to receive IV fluids, antibiotics, anticoagulation, and other medications
